intro: Abolboda acicularis var. granularis, commonly known as the granular needlegrass, is a perennial grass species native to arid and semi-arid regions of Central Asia. It is characterized by its slender, needle-like leaves that are covered in a fine, granular texture, giving it a distinctive appearance. The plant typically grows in compact clumps, with short, rhizomatous stems that help it survive in harsh, dry environments. Its inflorescence consists of dense, spike-like clusters of small, pale green to brownish flowers. This variety is well adapted to low-nutrient soils and can thrive in areas with minimal rainfall.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abolboda acicularis var. granularis is primarily native to the arid and semi-arid regions of central and western Australia. It is commonly found in sandy soils within the states of Queensland, New South Wales, and South Australia. This variety thrives in environments with low rainfall and high sun exposure. It is often associated with shrublands and open woodlands. Its distribution is limited to specific ecological zones where it can tolerate the harsh climatic conditions.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abolboda acicularis var. granularis was mainly introduced to areas with sandy or gravelly soils, particularly in arid and semi-arid regions.
